newsitem.title: USA: NHL board approves expansion to four US cities.
newsitem.headline: NHL board approves expansion to four US cities.

text.p: The National Hockey League's board of governor's Wednesday awarded new franchises to groups in Atlanta, Nashville, St. Paul and Columbus, Ohio.

The awarding of franchises will help spur the construction of new partly bond-financed arenas in Atlanta, St. Paul and Columbus and the issuance of additional debt for improvements at an arena in Nashville.
The Tennessee franchise will begin play in 1998, Georgia in 1999, the Minnesota team based in St. Paul in 2000 and Ohio in 2000, the league announced.
The board of governors also approved the relocation of the former Hartford Whalers franchise to North Carolina for the 1997-98 season. It has been renamed the Carolina Hurricanes.
The expansion will boost NHL membership to 30 teams by the end of the cycle. Each ownership group must pay an $80 million franchise fee.
A $213 million Atlanta arena would rely in part on $140 million of revenue bonds.

St. Paul has committed to $30 million of bonds for a new $130 million arena and pledged to issue another $65 million of debt if Minnesota lawmakers choose not to include it in a capital spending bill next year.
Columbus has approved private financing for a $125 million arena that would include more than $20 million of infrastructure improvements paid by the city and Franklin County.
The Nashville franchise will be majority-owned by Leipold Hockey Holdings LLC, jointly held by Craig Leipold and the S.C. Johnson family.
Turner Broadcasting System Inc, owner of the Atlanta Hawks basketball team, will own the Atlanta hockey franchise.
The Columbus team is expected to be owned by a group led by Worthington Industries Chairman John McConnell.
The St. Paul franchise will be held by a limited partnership led by billboard magnate Robert Naegele Jr.
The expansion committee recommended the four cities last week. It had also considered bids from Houston and Oklahoma City groups.
Each franchise must sell 12,000 season tickets by four months before the start of their first season, Commissioner Gary Bettman noted.
